results.headline: A Thief With Less Need for a Getaway Car

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Robber

results.summary_short: “The Robber,” based on a novel based on the exploits of an actual Austrian bank robber and long-distance runner, is the rare mash-up of genre material and art-house sensibility.

results.headline: Puppy Love and Bullies and a Bow-Tied Teacher

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of That's What I Am

results.summary_short: In “That’s What I Am” Ed Harris plays a middle-school teacher in 1965 who is a moral force in a small Southern California town.

results.headline: A Cynical Faith Healer Who Can’t Fix Himself

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sympathy for Delicious

results.summary_short: “Sympathy for Delicious,” the directorial feature debut of Mark Ruffalo, tells the story of a paraplegic D.J. turned faith healer.

results.headline: A Disney Take on the Big Night — Review

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prom

results.summary_short: In “Prom,” Aimee Teegarden plays a high school student organizing her class’s big night.

results.headline: In a Small Town, Big Life-Changers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lebanon, Pa.

results.summary_short: Abortion is the central issue riling up the characters as they argue over the choices facing a smart, pregnant, college-bound 17-year-old girl.

results.headline: Red Riding Hood, the Spy Caper

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hoodwinked Too! Hood vs. Evil

results.summary_short: “Hoodwinked Too! Hood vs. Evil” drops Red Riding Hood and other fairy-tale characters into a spy movie.

results.headline: Vrooooom! Vrooooom! Flex ’Em if You Got ’Em

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fast Five

results.summary_short: In “Fast Five” car chases (and more car chases) and muscle-bound men (Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson) keep the “Fast and Furious” franchise noisily crashing along.

results.headline: A TV Series Lost in Translation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exporting Raymond

results.summary_short: In “Exporting Raymond,” Phil Rosenthal, the creator of “Everybody Loves Raymond,” tells what happened when he tried to remake it for Russian TV.

results.headline: A Utopian Society Made Up of Business Moguls in Fedoras

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Atlas Shrugged Part One

results.summary_short: “Atlas Shrugged: Part I,” Ayn Rand’s opus from 1957, has its first adaptation for film.

results.headline: A Playwright’s Legacy, Kindled by Addiction and Neglect

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Arbor

results.summary_short: A playwright’s short and tragic life is recounted in a layered form, using actors lip-syncing actual interviews.

results.headline: A Fractious Family With Cancer on the Agenda

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Madea's Big Happy Family

results.summary_short: The latest movie in Tyler Perry’s “Madea” franchise goes lighter on the humor, heavier on the melodrama.

results.headline: Portrait of Childhood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of St. Nick

results.summary_short: “St. Nick” has a brother and sister on the run. “Pioneer” is a short that grows out of a bedtime story.

results.headline: The Hidden Persuaders Come Out in Full Force
results.display_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold

results.summary_short: A filmmaker dissects the world of product placement and advertising by making a documentary financed entirely by product placement and advertising.

results.headline: Bringing On the Vampires in ‘Stake Land’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stake Land

results.summary_short: In “Stake Land,” Jim Mickle brings on the vampires and fundamentalists in a postapocalyptic world.

results.headline: Scavenger Hunt for Family Secrets Across Time and Geography

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Incendies

results.summary_short: “Incendies,” Denis Villeneuve’s film based on a play by Wajdi Mouawad, is a family quest narrative that takes place in Quebec and an unnamed country resembling Lebanon.

results.headline: Japanese Survivors Shaded by Puzzlement and Sorrow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Children of Hiroshima

results.summary_short: The 1952 Japanese film “Children of Hiroshima” by Kaneto Shindo makes its United States debut as part of a retrospective devoted to Mr. Shindo at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

results.headline: A Warhol ‘Superstar,’ Closer to Earth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beautiful Darling

results.summary_short: “Beautiful Darling,” James Rasin’s documentary about the transsexual Warhol “superstar” Candy Darling, is also a meditation on the worship of movie stars.

results.headline: Longing for Marriage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When Harry Tries to Marry

results.summary_short: In “When Harry Tries to Marry,” a young man longs for an arranged Indian marriage.

results.headline: ‘The Bang Bang Club’ Shows Photojournalists at Work

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bang Bang Club

results.summary_short: “The Bang Bang Club” is based on a true story of photojournalists in South Africa.

results.headline: Love Triangle Sideshow, a Circus’s Main Attraction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Water for Elephants

results.summary_short: Francis Lawrence directs Reese Witherspoon and Robert Pattinson in “Water for Elephants,” a film adaptation of Sara Gruen’s novel about a Depression-era traveling circus.
